BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for extensive experience and a certain restraint. The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from northerly directions, wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at intermediate altitudes. During the course of the night they will increase in size additionally. They can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,.
The snowpack remains unfavourable on shady slopes.
Several medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Monday. On very steep slopes several small and medium-sized avalanches were released.
The weather conditions facilitated a gradual strengthening of the near-surface layers in particular on sunny slopes. The natural activity of dry and wet avalanches has rapidly decreased. Some large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are still even now possible. This applies in case of releases originating from steep, high-altitude starting zones that still retain some snow, in particular on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall until the early morning.
Over a wide area over a wide area 70 to 160 cm of snow fell on Sunday above approximately 1800 m.
The wind has transported some snow. Large wind slabs formed.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. New snow is lying on soft layers.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the night, in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Isolated natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.

Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep east, north and west facing slopes above approximately 2400 m.

An appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1200 m.

Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. This applies above approximately 2600 m. In some places new snow is lying on surface hoar.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and restraint. The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual settling of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: At intermediate and high altitudes the avalanche situation is dangerous. The conditions are precarious for backcountry touring outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow of the weekend as well as the wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released easily, or, in isolated cases naturally at intermediate and high altitudes. As a consequence of the moderate to strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations will increase in size on Wednesday.
Numerous large and, in isolated cases, very large dry and wet avalanches have been released until Tuesday.
The natural avalanche activity will appreciably decrease. Individual medium-sized to large natural avalanches are, however, not ruled out. They can occur in particular in starting zones where previous releases have taken place.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 80 to 120 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Sunday above approximately 2000 m. New snow is lying on soft layers. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is moist and its surface has a crust that is not capable of bearing a load.
As a consequence of snowfall and the strong easterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size at the weekend.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs represent the main danger. Backcountry touring is to be restricted to moderately steep terrain as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow of the weekend and in particular the wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released easily, or, in isolated cases naturally at intermediate and high altitudes. As a consequence of the moderate to strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations will increase in size on Wednesday.
Large and, in isolated cases, very large dry and wet avalanches have been released until Tuesday.
The natural avalanche activity will appreciably decrease. Some medium-sized to large natural avalanches are, however, not entirely ruled out.
At intermediate and high altitudes a dangerous avalanche situation will persist. Backcountry touring calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 50 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Sunday above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of snowfall and the occasionally strong easterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size.
Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise on Tuesday to increasing settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is moist and its surface has a crust that is not capable of bearing a load.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind. Weakly bonded old snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence. Fresh wind slabs at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and wind there will be an increase in the avalanche danger. Avalanches can be released in near-surface layers of the snowpack and reach quite a large size. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation individual natural avalanches are possible. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects above approximately 2400 m. Shady slopes where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Defensive route selection is recommended.

In addition the fresh wind slabs should be taken into account. They can be released by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

On rocky slopes dry loose snow avalanches are possible as the day progresses. In the event of prolonged bright spells this applies.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 60 cm of snow will fall. In some places new snow is lying on surface hoar. Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.

The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and restraint. Weakly bonded old snow represents the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs: Backcountry touring calls for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Strong northerly wind. The fresh wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. During the second half of the night they will increase in size additionally. They will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Single winter sport participants can release avalanches.
Some medium-sized natural avalanches are possible, especially on wind-loaded slopes.
Several medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Monday.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall until the early morning.
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1800 m.
The southeasterly wind has transported some snow. Sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the night, in particular on sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In high Alpine regions a critical avalanche situation will persist in some regions. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Sunday. As a consequence of the easterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally in high Alpine regions.
The fresh wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines.

The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The moderate wind has transported the new snow.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. Towards its surface, the snowpack is moist and its surface has a crust that is not capable of bearing a load.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some snow will fall over a wide area. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible as a consequence of the snowfall. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 1800 m.
Gliding avalanches can also occur, in particular on steep slopes below approximately 1800 m.
Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of snowfall and the wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.
The snowpack remains moist below approximately 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be partly cloudy over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow of Wednesday represents the main danger. This snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. The new snow can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line. Over a wide area 40 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and on steep slopes occasionally large loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, wind slabs will form in the course of the day especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area new snow is lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in particular on northwest to north to northeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular slopes adjacent to ridgelines are especially precarious. The snowpack will become unstable over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of the snowfall slab avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be unstable in particular on steep northeast, north and northwest facing slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Strong northerly wind. The fresh wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. During the second half of the night they will increase in size additionally.
They can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,.
Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.
Several medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Monday. On very steep slopes small and medium-sized avalanches were released.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall until the early morning.
Over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow fell on Sunday above approximately 1500 m.
The southeasterly wind has transported some snow.
The snowpack is favourably layered, in particular on shady slopes.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the night, in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack is frozen, but not to a significant depth and will soften quickly. Individual, then as the precipitation becomes heavier more, and in some cases even medium-sized, gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and snowfall the snowpack can not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep east, north and west facing slopes above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual settling of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. In addition individual gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in particular in the north. The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Moist loose snow slides require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack is not frozen and will already be soft in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of high temperatures and rain the snowpack could settle hardly at all.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow is to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Small avalanches are possible in isolated cases as before. Above approximately 1800 m and on steep west, north and east facing slopes the avalanche danger is one level higher. Also in gullies and bowls the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow of the last few days is lying on top of a weakly bonded old snowpack above approximately 1900 m. In some cases new snow is lying on a wet old snowpack.
